title: Should I say 'advance forward' or just 'forward'? - Quora

response.answer_text: ‘Advance’ is a verb meaning ‘move forward’. ‘Forward’ is an adverb meaning ‘toward the front.’ ‘Forward’ can’t be used as a verb except as a single word command. ‘The troops were all prepared and lined up. The general than said ‘Forward!’ and they all began moving toward the enemy in unison.’ ‘Advance forward’ is redundant; however it is appropriate in some cases to emphasize the action . ‘Advance to the next square on the game board.’ (a simple motion with little or no effort or consequence involved) vs ‘Advance forward in spite of the opposition.’ (moving forward with effort and consequence)

Advance in this context simply means to move or bring forward. While advance does imply forward due to it's purposeful and goal getting nature, I think you should say advance toward whatever your advancing to. This implies purpose to the readers, and they will know where they are going. However, if you simply wish to say they are moving in the forward direction relevant to their own perspective, then say they are moving forward.
Advance forward is redundant. You can go forward and you can advance. retreat means to go backwards, advance means to go forward.
